questions.text: An intern is asked to measure the blood pressure of a patient with cardiac tamponade. He/she should ask the patient to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Breathe normally:

  • When measuring blood pressure in a patient with cardiac tamponade, it is important to ensure that the patient is in a relaxed state and breathing normally. This is because taking deep breaths or holding the breath can potentially alter the intrathoracic pressure and affect the hemodynamic status of the patient.
  • Cardiac tamponade is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid or blood in the pericardial space, which puts pressure on the heart and impairs its ability to fill and pump effectively. This can lead to decreased cardiac output and compromised blood pressure.
  • In this scenario, it is crucial to measure the patient's blood pressure accurately to assess the severity of the tamponade and guide appropriate management. Asking the patient to breathe normally helps maintain stable intrathoracic pressure and provides a more accurate reflection of the patient's true blood pressure.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and C are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the potential risk of adding verapamil to a hypertensive patient already on metoprolol?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bradycardia with AV block:

  • Metoprolol is a beta-blocker medication that primarily works by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors in the heart, leading to a decrease in heart rate and cardiac contractility. Verapamil, on the other hand, is a calcium channel blocker that primarily acts by blocking calcium channels in the heart and blood vessels, resulting in vasodilation and a decrease in heart rate.
  • When verapamil is added to metoprolol, there is an increased risk of bradycardia (slow heart rate) with AV block (impairment of electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles). This is because both medications have negative chronotropic effects, meaning they decrease the heart rate. The combination of these drugs can potentiate this effect and lead to excessive slowing of the heart rate, potentially resulting in bradycardia and AV block.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding oculomotor nerve palsy is false?

choices.text: Loss of light reflex in the affected eye
Lateral and upward gaze in primary position

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lateral and upward gaze in primary position:

  • In a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy the presentation is abduction and depression in the primary gaze, i.e., eye is down and out. It is due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ptosis: Ptosis, or drooping of the eyelid, is a common symptom of oculomotor nerve palsy due to weakened levator palpebrae superioris muscle..

Option B - Mid-dilated pupil: This statement is true. Oculomotor nerve palsy can lead to a mid-dilated pupil due to parasympathetic palsy.

Option C - Loss of light reflex in the affected eye: Both the direct and consensual light reflex in the affected eye is absent.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suitable application for a stenopic slit?

choices.text: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Corneal tattooing:

  • The stenopic slit is not typically used for corneal tattooing. Corneal tattooing is a procedure in which pigment is injected into the cornea to alter its appearance. It is usually performed for cosmetic purposes like pterygium and pinguecula.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Fincham's test: A stenopeic slit can be used in Fincham's test to differentiate the halos of acute congestive glaucoma and immature cataract.

Option C - Optical iridectomy: A stenopaeic slit is used to determine the site of optical iridectomy.

Option D - To find out the axis in astigmatism: A stenopaeic slit can be used to detect the axis of astigmatism.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Drusen:

  • Drusen are yellowish-white deposits that accumulate between the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and Bruch's membrane in the retina. They can be seen as small, round or oval-shaped lesions in the histopathological image of the retina.
  • Drusen are a characteristic finding in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), particularly in the early stages known as dry AMD. They are thought to be accumulations of extracellular material, including lipids and proteins, which can disrupt the normal functioning of the retina and its blood supply.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hard exudates: Hard exudates are lipid deposits that can be seen as yellow or white lesions in the retina. They typically appear as small, round or elongated deposits with well-defined borders associated with diabetic retinopathy.

Option C - Cotton wool spots: Cotton-wool spots are composed of accumulations of neuronal debris within the nerve fiber layer characterized by small fluffy whitish superficial lesions that obscure underlying blood vessels associated with diabetic and hypertensive retinopathy.


Option D - Microaneurysms: Microaneurysms are localized saccular outpouchings of the capillary wall that may form by focal dilatation of the capillary wall where pericytes are absent or by fusion of two arms of a capillary loop seen in diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: What is the adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Atropine Sulfate eye ointment:

  • Atropine Sulfate eye ointment is the adjuvant therapy commonly used in fungal corneal ulcers.
    • To reduce pain from ciliary spasms.
    • To prevent the formation of posterior synechiae.
    • It increases the blood supply to the anterior uvea by relieving pressure on the anterior ciliary arteries and brings more antibodies into the aqueous humor.
    • It also reduces exudation by decreasing hyperemia and vascular permeability.

Incorrect Option:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. These are not used as the adjunctive therapy for fungal keratitis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old was brought with the complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT scan showed a well – defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rhabdomyosarcoma:

  • "Rhabdomyosarcoma" is the probable diagnosis based on the given information.
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor that arises from embryonal cells of skeletal muscle origin. It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children and can occur in various locations, including the orbit. The clinical presentation of an orbital rhabdomyosarcoma often includes proptosis (protrusion of the eye), without a history of fever.
  • The CT scan findings of a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction are consistent with the characteristics of rhabdomyosarcoma..
  • The biopsy findings of small, round cells that are positive for Desmin, and Desmin is a marker of rhabdomyosarcomas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina, which is the inner layer of the eye. It typically presents as leukocoria , strabismus , or visual impairment.

Option B - Cavernous hemangioma: Cavernous hemangioma is a benign vascular tumor that can occur in the orbit. It is characterized by a collection of dilated blood vessels.

Option C - Orbital Cellulitis: Orbital cellulitis is an infection involving the soft tissues around the eye. It typically presents with eyelid swelling, erythema, pain, fever, proptosis, restricted eye movements.

questions.text: A 30 year old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. Upon examination, corneal ulcer with feathery ends and satellite lesions around it are seen. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fungal corneal ulcer:

  • The most likely pathology in this case is a fungal corneal ulcer. The history of an eye injury caused by a leaf, along with symptoms of pain, photophobia, redness, and examination revealing corneal ulcer with feathery edges (hyphae) surrounded by satellite lesions are suggestive of fungal keratitis..

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior uveitis: It typically presents with pain, redness, photophobia , and blurred vision, keratic precipitates, and aqueous flare.

Option B - Conjunctivitis: It is characterized by redness, pain, photophobia, discharge depending on the infecting organism, follicles or papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva.

Option D - HSV corneal ulcer: Ulcer caused by herpes simplex virus usually presents with superficial punctate keratitis and dendritic ulcer which may progress to geographical ulcer.

questions.text: Identify the marked layer of the retina
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inner plexiform layer:

  • Inner plexiform layer- is marked in the given image
  • The inner plexiform layer is one of the distinct layers within the retina, and it is located between the inner nuclear layer and the ganglion cell layer. It plays a crucial role in the transmission of visual information from the photoreceptor cells to the ganglion cells as it contains the synapse of ganglion.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ganglion cell layer : Ganglion cell layer is just present between the inner plexiform layer and nerve fiber layer.

Option C - Inner nuclear layer: Inner nuclear layer is present between the inner and outer plexiform layer and contains the bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and horizontal cells.

Option D - Outer plexiform layer: The outer plexiform layer is located between the outer nuclear layer and the inner segments of the photoreceptor cells and has the synapses of axons of rods and cones with the dendrites of bipolar cells/amacrine cells/horizontal cells.

questions.text: A 6-year- old child is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. He has a large port-wine stain on the left side of her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most ocular manifestation of the underlying condition ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glaucoma:

  • The clinical presentation of the seizures, port wine stain on face, and leptomeningeal angioma is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome.
  • The ocular manifestation of Sturge-Weber syndrome is congenital glaucoma..

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Sturge-Weber syndrome is not associated with these diseases.

questions.text: Which disease is associated with bilateral optic neuritis and transverse myelitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Neuromyelitis optica:

  • Neuromyelitis optica (NMO), also known as Devic's disease, is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the optic nerves and the spinal cord. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of bilateral optic neuritis, and can present with transverse myelitis, inflammation of the spinal cord, is also commonly associated with NMO.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Schilder disease: It is characterized by breakdown of the myelin over nerves in the brain and spinal cord and present with bilateral optic neuritis.

Options B - Parainfectious optic neuritis: Optic neuritis with infectious cause is known as parainfectious disease. It is not associated with transverse myelitis.

Option D - Multiple sclerosis: Multiple sclerosis is the most common cause of optic neuritis and presents unilaterally.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus:

  • "Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF)" is the site of the lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), it is between the third, fourth and sixth nuclei.
  • It is characterized by defective ipsilateral adduction, and the contralateral abducting eye showing ataxic nystagmus.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for reference.

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hypothermia:

  • Paradoxical undressing is a phenomenon commonly observed in cases of severe hypothermia. Hypothermia is a condition characterized by a dangerously low body temperature, usually below 35 degrees Celsius (95 degrees Fahrenheit).
  •  This behavior is thought to result from the disorientation and confusion caused by hypothermia, as well as the dilation of blood vessels near the skin's surface, which can create a false sensation of warmth.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Heart stress: It is not associated with paradoxical undressing.

Option B - Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a paraphilic disorder characterized by an individual's sexual interest and pleasure derived from observing others without their consent. It is unrelated to paradoxical undressing.

Option D - LSD overdose: Overdosing on LSD can cause a variety of physical and psychological effects, but paradoxical undressing is not a known symptom.

questions.text:
The X-ray image of a patient presented to the casualty is given below.

How will you manage this case?
questions.solution:
Answer: Tension band wiring

Justification:

  • Olecranon fractures are commonly managed surgically if displaced.

  • Tension band wiring (TBW) is the standard treatment for simple, transverse, or minimally comminuted olecranon fractures.

  • TBW converts tensile forces from the triceps into compressive forces at the fracture site during elbow movement, promoting healing.

Olecranon Fracture 

Aspect Details
Anatomy Olecranon is part of the proximal ulna and serves as the insertion for the triceps
Mechanism of Injury Direct trauma or fall on outstretched hand with elbow flexed
Clinical Features Pain, swelling, inability to extend the elbow
X-ray Findings Fracture line at the olecranon, often transverse or comminuted
Non-operative Treatment Immobilization in nondisplaced fractures (rare)
Operative Treatment Depends on fracture type:
  Tension band wiring for transverse/simple fractures
  Plating for comminuted or unstable fractures

 

Nailing (Option A): Incorrect because intramedullary nailing is not used for olecranon fractures; it’s suited for long bone diaphyseal fractures (e.g., femur, tibia).

Plating (Option B): Incorrect for simple fractures; plating is reserved for comminuted or unstable olecranon fractures, not first-line in simple transverse ones.

Knee splint (Option D): Incorrect because this is irrelevant to the elbow; used for lower limb injuries.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic method depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Darkfield Microscopy:

  • Darkfield microscopy is a specialized technique used for visualizing thin structures that are difficult to see using conventional brightfield microscopy. In darkfield microscopy, the specimen appears bright against a dark background, which enhances the contrast and visibility of certain structures as seen in the image.
  • In darkfield microscopy, a special condenser is used to block the direct light from reaching the objective lens. Instead, oblique or angled illumination i.e., reflected light is employed, causing light to be scattered or refracted by the specimen. This scattered light enters the objective lens and forms the image against a dark background.
  • Darkfield microscopy is particularly useful for visualizing thin structures like flagella, treponema, and spirochetes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Phase contrast Microscopy: Phase contrast microscopy is a different optical technique used to enhance the contrast of transparent or low-contrast specimens. It converts slight differences in refractive index and cell density into easily detectable variations in light intensity. It is useful to study microbial motility and detecting microbial internal cellular components.

Option C - Fluorescent Microscopy: Fluorescent microscopy is a method that utilizes fluorophores to label specific structures or molecules within a specimen. It requires the use of fluorescent dyes or fluorescently labeled antibodies. In fluorescent microscopy, the specimen emits fluorescence when illuminated by specific wavelengths of light, resulting in a bright, colorful image against a dark background.

Option D - Electron Microscopy: Electron microscopy uses a beam of accelerated electrons instead of light to image the specimen. It provides extremely high-resolution images, allowing for the visualization of ultrastructural details of cells and tissues.

questions.text: A 10-year-old patient presented to the Outpatient Department (OPD) with an upper limb deformity. An X-ray image is provided. What is the most probable fracture responsible for this deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Supracondylar Fracture:

  • Supracondylar fractures are common fractures in children, particularly in the elbow region. They occur just above the condyle of the humerus, which is the bony prominence at the lower end of the upper arm bone. These fractures can result in a characteristic deformity known as "Gartland Type III" or "posteromedial angulation" deformity.
  • The deformity in a supracondylar fracture typically presents with the following features:
    • Angulation: There is an abnormal bending or angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm.
    • Displacement: The distal fragment (lower arm bone) moves posteriorly or towards the back of the arm, causing a noticeable deformity.
    • Swelling and pain: The affected elbow may also exhibit swelling, tenderness, and pain.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Olecranon Fracture:

  • An olecranon fracture refers to a fracture of the bony prominence at the back of the elbow, called the olecranon process. This fracture typically results from a direct blow or fall on the elbow. While an olecranon fracture can cause pain, swelling, and limited movement of the elbow, it does not typically cause the characteristic deformity described in the question. The deformity associated with an olecranon fracture usually involves a visible gap or step-off at the back of the elbow rather than an angulation or displacement of the forearm.

Option C - Radial Head Fracture:

  • A radial head fracture involves a fracture of the head of the radius bone, which is located near the elbow joint. This type of fracture is commonly seen after a fall on an outstretched hand. While a radial head fracture can cause pain, tenderness, and a limited range of motion in the elbow, it does not typically result in the specific deformity described in the question. The deformity associated with a radial head fracture is often localized to the area around the elbow joint, rather than involving a noticeable angulation or displacement of the forearm.

Option D - Triad of Elbow:

  • The "Triad of Elbow" refers to a specific pattern of injury involving dislocation of the elbow joint, along with fractures of the radial head and coronoid process of the ulna. This complex injury pattern is typically seen in high-energy trauma, such as a fall from a height or a motor vehicle accident. While the Triad of Elbow can cause significant deformity and instability of the elbow joint, it is less likely to be the cause of the described deformity in a 10-year-old patient presenting to the OPD. The Triad of Elbow is relatively uncommon in pediatric patients, and a supracondylar fracture is a more frequent and likely cause of the described deformity in this age group.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - RNA:

  • Northern blotting is a laboratory technique used to study gene expression by detecting and analyzing mRNA. It involves the separation of RNA molecules based on their size using gel electrophoresis, followed by their transfer onto a solid support membrane (usually nylon or nitrocellulose). The transferred RNA molecules are then immobilized on the membrane.
  • To detect specific RNA molecules, the membrane is hybridized with a labeled nucleic acid probe that is complementary to the target RNA sequence of interest. The probe binds specifically to its complementary RNA sequence on the membrane, allowing the detection and visualization of the target RNA molecule.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DNA: Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA molecules.

Option C - Proteins: Western blotting, immunohistochemistry, or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) are commonly used for protein detection and analysis.

Option D - None: Northern blotting is specifically used for the detection of RNA molecules.

questions.text: The following image depicts :
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Production of monoclonal antibodies:

  • Image depicting the process shown, which is the production of monoclonal antibodies
  • Monoclonal antibodies are antibodies that are produced against an antigen with single epitope that stimulates only single clone of B cells, known as hybridoma cells.

The image likely represents the steps involved in the hybridoma technology, which is a widely used method for generating monoclonal antibodies. This process typically includes the following steps:

  1. Immunization: An animal, such as a mouse, is immunized with the target antigen to stimulate the production of specific antibodies by B cells.
  2. Harvesting antibody-producing cells: Antibody-producing cells, specifically the B cells, are isolated from the immunized animal, typically from the spleen or lymph nodes.
  3. Fusion: The isolated B cells are fused with myeloma cells, which are immortal tumor cells. This fusion creates hybridoma cells that possess the ability to produce antibodies indefinitely.
  4. Screening and selection: The hybridoma cells are screened and selected based on their ability to produce the desired antibody. This involves testing the specificity and affinity of the antibodies produced by different hybridoma clones.
  5. Cloning: Selected hybridoma cells are cloned to obtain pure and stable cell lines, ensuring the consistent production of the desired monoclonal antibody.
  6. Antibody production: The established hybridoma cell lines are cultured in the laboratory to produce large quantities of the specific monoclonal antibody.

Incorrect Option:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with a painless deformity. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. The most common cause of this deformity is____.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rickets:

  • Rickets is a condition that primarily affects growing children and is caused by a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. It leads to impaired bone mineralization, resulting in weakened and softened bones. The deformities commonly associated with rickets include bowed legs (genu varum) or knock knees (genu valgum).
  • Rickets-related genu varum (bowed legs) typically presents as a deformity where the legs curve outward, causing a distinct bowing appearance. This deformity is often painless but can affect a child's gait and overall physical development.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Skeletal Dysplasia:

  • Skeletal dysplasia refers to a group of disorders characterized by abnormal bone development and growth. While skeletal dysplasia can cause various types of deformities, it is a broad term encompassing multiple specific conditions. Without further details or specific indications from the radiograph, it is difficult to determine if skeletal dysplasia is the most common cause of the deformity in this case.

Option C - Scurvy:

  • Scurvy is a condition caused by vitamin C deficiency and primarily affects collagen synthesis. It can lead to various symptoms, including weakness, fatigue, gum disease, and impaired wound healing. While scurvy can cause musculoskeletal symptoms, such as joint pain and muscle weakness, it is not typically associated with painless deformities of the legs.

Option D - Blount Disease:

  • Blount disease, also known as tibia vara, is a growth disorder that affects the tibia (shinbone). It primarily occurs in young children and is characterized by inward bowing of the lower leg, leading to a "knock-knee" appearance. Blount disease can cause painless deformities in the legs, but it is less common than rickets in the given age group

questions.text: Which infection is characterized by the presence of bloody diarrhea, liver abscess, and right upper quadrant pain, and histology of colon biopsy shows flask-shaped ulcers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Entamoeba Histolytica:

  • The clinical presentation of bloody diarrhea, liver abscess, and flask-shaped ulcer is suggestive of Amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica.
  • The most commonly affected organ is the intestine leading to bloody diarrhea (traveler's diarrhea) and appendicitis. The most common extraintestinal infection occurs in liver which may lead to amebic liver abscess (anchovy sauce).
  • A colon biopsy shows a flask-shaped ulcer is characteristic of Entamoeba histolytica. The trophozoites of E. histolytica damage the mucosa and submucosa but cannot damage the muscular as it is difficult to break. Thus, it starts breaking the submucosa on the sides, resulting in a flask-shaped ulcer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Giardia Lamblia: It is responsible for causing giardiasis characterized by steatorrhea due to malabsorption, not dysentery.

Option C - Campylobacter Jejuni: This is a gram-negative bacteria that causes fever, bloody diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It is diagnosed by gram staining showing darting motility or by growing in culture.

Option D - Staphylococcus Aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacteria that can cause various infections, including food poisoning characterized by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. It can be diagnosed by gram staining and culture medium.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naïve T-cells ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulators of naïve T-cells. Dendritic cells are antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that play a critical role in initiating and regulating immune responses. They are found in various tissues and are particularly abundant in lymphoid organs.
  • When dendritic cells encounter antigens, such as microbial pathogens or tumor cells, they capture and process these antigens. Subsequently, they migrate to lymphoid organs, such as lymph nodes, where they present the processed antigens to naïve T-cells.
  • Mature dendritic cells express high levels of co-stimulatory molecules, such as CD80 and CD86, as well as major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. These molecules are necessary for effective T-cell activation. When a naïve T-cell recognizes its specific antigen presented by a mature dendritic cell, a complex series of signaling events occur, leading to T-cell activation and proliferation.
  • The interaction between naïve T-cells and mature dendritic cells is crucial for initiating adaptive immune responses. It leads to the differentiation of naïve T-cells into effector T-cells, such as cytotoxic T-cells or helper T-cells, which carry out specific immune functions to eliminate the pathogen or mediate immune responses.

Incorrect Option:

Option B. Follicular dendritic cells: Follicular dendritic cells (FDCs) are specialized stromal cells found in lymphoid follicles, particularly in the germinal centers of lymph nodes. They play a crucial role in the organization of B-cell areas and the generation of antibody responses. While FDCs interact with B-cells, they are not the primary stimulators of naïve T-cells.

Option C. B lymphocytes: B lymphocytes, also known as B cells, are a type of white blood cell involved in humoral immune responses mediated by antibodies. B cells can present antigens to helper T-cells and receive signals from them for proper activation and differentiation. However, mature dendritic cells are generally considered more potent in stimulating naïve T-cells compared to B cells.

Option D. NK cells: Natural killer (NK) cells are a type of cytotoxic lymphocyte that plays a role in innate immune responses, particularly in the early defense against viral infections and tumor surveillance. NK cells are not primarily involved in the stimulation of naïve T-cells, as their main function is to directly recognize and kill infected or abnormal cells.

questions.text: The bone marrow aspirate from a patient revealed the following findings as seen in the image. Which of the following statements is correct about the disease?

choices.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
It is an obligate extracellular parasite
Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite:

  • The given image is Leishman Donovan bodies, which are macrophages-laden amastigotes, which are ovoid or rounded cells, about 2-4 μm in size, suggesting Leishmaniasis. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by the protozoan parasites of the Leishmania genus. These parasites infect various tissues of the body, including the bone marrow.
  • The gold standard test to diagnose leishmaniasis is by demonstration of the amastigote in peripheral blood, bone marrow aspirate, spleen aspirate, and large lymph nodes. Examination of buffy coat is best to examine for amastigote in peripheral blood smear. Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, with more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It is an obligate extracellular parasite: Leishmania parasites are obligate intracellular parasites, specifically residing inside macrophages and other immune cells. They are obligate intracellular parasites and require host cells for their survival and replication.

Option C - It is transmitted by culex: Leishmaniasis is primarily transmitted to humans through the bites of infected female sandflies.

Option D - Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India: The choice of treatment for leishmaniasis depends on various factors, including the species of Leishmania causing the infection and the geographical location. The drug of choice to treat leishmaniasis is liposomal amphotericin B, which is also used as a first-line treatment in different regions.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A

  • Episiotomy scissors are surgical scissors specifically designed for performing an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum (the area between the vagina and anus) during childbirth to facilitate a controlled and easier delivery. Episiotomy scissors have a specific shape and size to ensure precise and controlled cutting of the perineal tissue
  1. Curved Blades: Episiotomy scissors have curved blades that are specifically designed for making precise incisions during the procedure. Look for the distinctive curve in the blades, which helps in accessing and cutting the perineal tissue effectively.
  2. Shorter Length: Episiotomy scissors are generally shorter in length compared to other surgical scissors. They are designed to be maneuverable in the limited space of the perineal area during childbirth.
  3. Pointed or Angled Tips: The tips of episiotomy scissors may be slightly pointed or angled to allow for better control and accuracy while making the incision. This feature helps in achieving a clean and controlled cut.
  4. Finger Rings: Look for the presence of finger rings on the handles of the scissors. Episiotomy scissors typically have finger rings that allow the surgeon or healthcare professional to comfortably grip and manipulate the instrument during the procedure.

Incorrect Option:

Option B. Curved Artery Forceps: Curved artery forceps, also known as curved hemostatic forceps, have a curved shape and are designed to clamp or control bleeding from blood vessels during surgical procedures. They are commonly used in vascular surgeries to grasp and occlude arteries or veins. The curved shape of artery forceps is not suitable for making the precise incision required in an episiotomy.

Option C. Curve-Bladed Mayo Scissors: Curve-bladed Mayo scissors have a curved shape and are used as general-purpose surgical scissors. They are commonly used for cutting and dissecting tissues during various surgical procedures. However, their curved design and general-purpose nature make them less suitable for the specific requirements of an episiotomy, which requires a specialized instrument with a specific blade shape and size.

Option D. Mosquito Forceps: Mosquito forceps, also known as mosquito hemostats, are fine, straight forceps that are commonly used to control bleeding from small blood vessels or to hold delicate tissues during surgeries. They have a straight shape and are not designed for making incisions or performing surgical procedures that involve cutting through tissues. Therefore, they are not suitable for performing an episiotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following investigative procedures does not require the use of real-time PCR to determine viral load?

choices.text: Person with hepatitis B on tenofovir therapy
Detection of HSV causing temporal encephalitis
BK virus in patient of allograft renal transplant
CMV in patient of liver transplant

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Detection of HSV Causing Temporal Encephalitis:

  • Real-time PCR is used for the quantification, hence real-time PCR is not preferred for detection of HSV causing temporal encephalitis, instead conventional PCR is preferred for the detection of the HSV DNA in cerebrospinal fluid. It can also differentiate between HSV 1 and HSV 2. Monitoring viral load is not routinely performed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Person with Hepatitis B on Tenofovir Therapy: In individuals with hepatitis B receiving tenofovir therapy, monitoring the viral load using real-time PCR is essential. It helps determine the response to treatment, assess viral suppression, and evaluate the risk of drug resistance.

Option C - BK Virus in a Patient with Allograft Renal Transplant: BK virus infection can occur in patients who have undergone renal transplantation. Monitoring the viral load using real-time PCR in urine or blood samples is important to detect and manage BK virus-associated complications, such as nephropathy. 

Option D - CMV in a Patient with Liver Transplant: Cytomegalovirus infection is a significant concern in patients undergone solid organ transplantation. Real-time PCR for CMV viral load in blood is commonly performed in these patients to monitor for active infection, guide antiviral therapy, and assess response to treatment.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C

  • Explanation: Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) pregnancy refers to a type of multiple pregnancy where twins share the same chorionic sac (monochorionic) and the same amniotic sac (monoamniotic). This means that both twins develop within a single sac, with no membrane separating them.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS): TTTS is a condition that can occur in monochorionic pregnancies where there is an imbalance in blood flow between the twins sharing the same placenta. This can lead to one twin receiving too much blood (donor twin) and the other receiving too little (recipient twin). TTTS is not specific to monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancies, and it can occur in other types of monochorionic pregnancies as well.

Option B. Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy: In a monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) pregnancy, twins share the same chorionic sac (monochorionic) but have separate amniotic sacs (diamniotic). This means that each twin has its own individual sac within the shared chorionic sac. MCDA pregnancies are more common than monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancies.

Option D. Dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy: In a dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) pregnancy, each twin has its own separate chorionic and amniotic sacs. This means that each twin has its own individual sacs for both the placenta and the amniotic fluid. DCDA pregnancies are the most common type of twin pregnancy and are considered lower risk compared to monochorionic pregnancies.

questions.text: What would be regarded as an absolute contraindication for the insertion of a copper T in a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Previous ectopic pregnancy:

Explanation:

  • Insertion of a copper intrauterine device (IUD), commonly known as Copper T, is generally safe and effective for most women.Women who have had an ectopic pregnancy are at a higher risk of having another ectopic pregnancy in the future. Therefore, inserting an IUD in a woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy can increase the risk of another ectopic pregnancy and its complications, making it an absolute contraindication.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Unmotivated patient: A lack of motivation is not an absolute contraindication for IUD insertion. However, healthcare providers should ensure that the patient understands the benefits, risks, and proper usage of the IUD before insertion.

Option B - Menorrhagia: Menorrhagia, which is heavy menstrual bleeding, is not an absolute contraindication for IUD insertion. In fact, copper IUDs are sometimes used to treat menorrhagia by reducing menstrual bleeding.

Option D - Previous history of abortion: A previous history of abortion, especially if uncomplicated, is not an absolute contraindication for IUD insertion. In fact, IUD insertion can be done after a safe abortion procedure, providing effective contraception for the future.

questions.text: A female comes to Gynecology OPD for pre-conceptual counseling, with 2 prior second trimester abortions. What is the next investigation you will advise?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hysterosalpingography:

  • Hysterosalpingography is a procedure that involves the injection of a contrast dye into the uterus and fallopian tubes to assess their patency. While it can be useful in evaluating the fallopian tubes' blockages or abnormalities, it is the the initial investigation in a case of recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Anatomic abnormalities are responsible for 10–15% of recurrent abortion. The causes may be congenital or acquired. Congenital anomalies may be due to defects in the Müllerian duct fusion or resorption (e.g. unicornuate, bicornuate, septate or double uterus).
    Hysterosalpingography showing bicornuate uterus

​​​​​​​

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pelvic sonography- This option is incorrect

Option C - Endometrial Biopsy: While endometrial biopsy can help identify certain uterine abnormalities or infections, it may not be the initial investigation in a case of recurrent pregnancy loss.

Option D - Karyotyping of the parents: While parental karyotyping may be considered in cases of recurrent pregnancy loss, it is typically not the first investigation performed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with submucosal fibroid was undergoing myomectomy. The surgeon was using 1.5% glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. During the surgery, the nurse informs that there is a 500ml deficit of the irrigating fluid. What is the next step to be done?

choices.text: Change the fluid to normal saline
Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status:

  • While performing a myomectomy fluids may be used to distend the uterus for visualization and manipulation.
  • Fluid can escape into the peritoneal cavity or circulation and careful monitoring of fluids is essential during the procedure.
  • The surgery can be continued in this instance as the deficit is 500ml and careful monitoring will be necessary.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stop the surgery: Stopping the surgery based solely on a 500ml deficit of the irrigating fluid may not be necessary, especially if the patient's vital signs and overall condition are stable.

Option B - Change the fluid to normal saline: While changing the irrigating fluid to normal saline may be an option, it is not the immediate next step in this scenario. In some cases, glycine is preferred for its specific properties, such as maintaining a clear surgical field and minimizing thermal injury.

Option D - Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery: Furosemide is a diuretic medication used to increase urine output. Administering furosemide to address a fluid deficit during surgery may not be necessary or appropriate.

questions.text: A 20 year old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed normal uterus but gonads weren't detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Swyer's syndrome:

  • Swyer's syndrome is a rare genetic condition characterized by the presence of a 46XY karyotype (typically associated with males) in individuals who have female external genitalia at birth.
  • It is caused by a mutation or deletion in the SRY gene, which is responsible for testicular development. In Swyer's syndrome, the gonads (testes) do not develop properly and are replaced by fibrous tissue, leading to primary amenorrhea and poor breast development. The internal reproductive structures, such as the uterus, may be present and appear normal.

Incorrect Options:


Option A - Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is a condition in which individuals with a 46XY karyotype have partial or complete insensitivity to androgens (male sex hormones).  

Option B - Turner syndrome: In Turner syndrome, the ovaries are usually underdeveloped or absent. However, the karyotype in Turner syndrome is 45X (45 chromosomes with a missing X chromosome), whereas the scenario describes a 46XY karyotype, ruling out Turner syndrome.
 

Option C - True hermaphrodite: True hermaphrodites can have a variety of karyotypes, including 46XX, 46XY, or mosaic karyotypes. However, in the given scenario, gonads are not detected, which is not consistent with true hermaphroditism

questions.text: A woman presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is being taken for Cesarean section. Which of the following is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on the OT table?

choices.text: Supine with wedge under right hip

questions.solution:
Correct Option A

  • In the case of a woman presenting with prolonged labor and requiring a Cesarean section, the appropriate position for the patient on the operating table is supine with a wedge under the right hip.
  • Supine with a wedge under the right hip: This position is commonly used during Cesarean sections. The patient lies flat on her back (supine) with a wedge or pillow placed under the right hip. This positioning helps to tilt the uterus to the left, reducing pressure on the vena cava and improving blood flow to the fetus. It also helps to prevent supine hypotensive syndrome, a condition that can occur when the weight of the uterus compresses the vena cava, leading to decreased blood flow and potential complications.

Incorrect Option:

Option B. Semi fowlers: The semi-fowlers position involves the patient sitting up at a 30-45 degree angle. While this position is commonly used for patient comfort in non-operative settings, it is not the recommended position for a Cesarean section. It does not provide the optimal access and exposure required for the surgical procedure.

Option C. Trendelenburg with legs in stirrups: The Trendelenburg position involves tilting the operating table with the head down and the legs elevated. This position is not routinely used during a Cesarean section. It may be utilized in certain specific situations, such as when there is a need to displace abdominal contents or improve exposure in complicated cases. However, it is not the standard position for a routine Cesarean section.

Option D. Prone position: The prone position involves lying face down. It is not the appropriate position for a Cesarean section as it does not provide the necessary access to the abdominal and pelvic areas for the surgical procedure.

questions.text: Identify the procedure done in the labor room?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C

  • Cardiotocography (CTG): CTG is a procedure commonly performed in the labor room to monitor the fetal heart rate (cardio) and uterine contractions (toco). It involves placing sensors on the mother's abdomen to record the fetal heart rate and the timing and duration of contractions. CTG is used to assess fetal well-being and monitor for any signs of fetal distress during labor.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Amniocentesis: Amniocentesis is a procedure performed during pregnancy to collect a sample of amniotic fluid for diagnostic purposes. It is typically performed in an ultrasound-guided setting, not in the labor room. Therefore, amniocentesis is not the correct procedure done in the labor room.

Option B. MCA doppler: MCA doppler refers to the transcranial Doppler ultrasound evaluation of the middle cerebral artery. It is a diagnostic procedure used to assess blood flow velocity in the fetal brain. While it may be performed during pregnancy, it is not specifically done in the labor room. Therefore, MCA doppler is not the correct procedure done in the labor room.

Option D. Amniotic fluid index determination: The amniotic fluid index (AFI) determination is a prenatal ultrasound measurement used to assess the quantity of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus. It is typically performed during regular antenatal check-ups and not specifically done in the labor room. Therefore, determining the amniotic fluid index is not the correct procedure done in the labor room

questions.text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4mm:

  • In cases of postmenopausal bleeding, transvaginal ultrasonography is commonly used to assess the endometrial thickness. An endometrial thickness of 4mm or greater is often used as the threshold for considering an endometrial biopsy in cases of postmenopausal bleeding. It indicates a thicker endometrial lining that may require further investigation to rule out potential abnormalities.

Incorrect Option:

Option A, C, and D: These statements are incorrect

questions.text: A pregnant woman delivered a baby with the normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half an hour she started bleeding per vaginal. On examination, she was hypotensive and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. USG showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B

  • The given scenario, the likely diagnosis is placenta succenturiata. Placenta succenturiata is a condition in which there are accessory or accessory lobes of placental tissue connected to the main placenta by blood vessels. These accessory lobes can be retained in the uterus after the delivery of the main placenta, leading to postpartum bleeding.
  • Placenta succenturiata: This is the correct answer. Placenta succenturiata refers to the presence of accessory lobes of placental tissue that are connected to the main placenta by blood vessels. Retention of these accessory lobes can lead to postpartum bleeding, which is consistent with the clinical presentation described in the question.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Placenta membranacea: Placenta membranacea is a condition characterized by a thin placental membrane that covers the entire chorionic surface. It is a rare condition and is not associated with postpartum bleeding or the presence of accessory lobes.

Option C. Circummarginate placenta: Circummarginate placenta is a condition in which the placenta has an irregular or scalloped margin. While it can be associated with an increased risk of postpartum bleeding, it does not involve the presence of accessory lobes as seen in placenta succenturiata.

Option D. Circumvallate placenta: Circumvallate placenta is a condition in which the placenta has a raised, rolled-up margin. It is associated with an increased risk of complications such as placental abruption, but it is not directly related to postpartum bleeding caused by retained placental tissue.

questions.text: A patient from a North-Eastern state was diagnosed to have an infection with P. falciparum malaria. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. A

  • Artemether plus lumefantrine: This is a recommended combination therapy for the treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria. Artemether is an artemisinin derivative that rapidly kills malaria parasites, while lumefantrine is a longer-acting antimalarial drug that helps to clear the remaining parasites and prevent the development of resistance. This combination is effective against P. falciparum and is widely used as a first-line treatment in many regions.

Incorrect options 

Option B. Sulfadoxine plus pyrimethamine: This combination was historically used as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated malaria caused by P. falciparum. However, due to the widespread development of resistance to this combination, it is no longer recommended as a first-line treatment in many regions, including areas with high P. falciparum prevalence. Resistance to sulfadoxine plus pyrimethamine has limited its effectiveness as an antimalarial therapy.

Option C. Chloroquine: Chloroquine was once the drug of choice for the treatment of malaria, including P. falciparum malaria. However, the emergence of chloroquine-resistant strains of P. falciparum has rendered chloroquine ineffective in many parts of the world, including North-Eastern states. It is no longer recommended as a first-line treatment for P. falciparum malaria in areas where resistance is prevalent.

Option D. Mefloquine: Mefloquine is an antimalarial drug primarily used as a prophylactic treatment to prevent malaria in individuals traveling to endemic regions. While it can also be used for the treatment of malaria, it is typically considered an alternative option rather than a first-line treatment. Its use may be warranted in specific cases or regions where resistance to other antimalarials is present.

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Carcinoma vulva:

  • The inguinofemoral group of lymph nodes are the most common lymph nodes in vulval carcinoma.
  • The sentinel lymph node for the vulva is the inguinofemoral group of lymph nodes.
  • SLN biopsy helps determine whether cancer cells have spread to the regional lymph nodes in the groin area. It allows for targeted evaluation of the specific lymph nodes most likely to be affected, enabling accurate staging and guiding subsequent treatment decisions.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Carcinoma vagina: SLN biopsy is less commonly used in Carcinoma vagina compared to other gynecological malignancies. Lymph node involvement in Carcinoma vagina varies, and SLN biopsy may not always be applicable or necessary.

Option C - Carcinoma cervix: SLN biopsy is not routinely performed in Carcinoma cervix. The standard approach for assessing lymph node involvement in Carcinoma cervix is pelvic lymphadenectomy or systemic lymph node sampling.

Option D - Carcinoma endometrium: SLN biopsy is not commonly performed in Carcinoma endometrium. The primary approach for evaluating lymph node involvement in Carcinoma endometrium is a systematic lymphadenectomy, particularly in cases with high-risk features.

questions.text: Which of the following changes can be seen in the quadruple screening for Down syndrome?

choices.text: Elevated ß-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP
Elevated ß-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP
Lower ß-hCG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP
Lower ß-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • The quadruple screening, also known as the quadruple test or quad test, is a prenatal screening test performed between 15 and 20 weeks of pregnancy to assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome (Trisomy 21).
  • The quadruple screening measures four substances in the maternal blood:
    • ß-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin): In pregnancies affected by Down syndrome, ß-hCG levels are often higher than normal.
    • Inhibin A: Elevated levels of inhibin A have been associated with an increased risk of Down syndrome.
    • Estriol: Estriol is a form of estrogen produced by the placenta. In pregnancies affected by Down syndrome, estriol levels are typically lower than expected.
    • AFP (alpha-fetoprotein): AFP levels are typically lower in pregnancies affected by Down syndrome.
  • Elevated ß-hCG, Inhibin, and lower estriol, AFP: This is the correct answer. Elevated ß-hCG and inhibin levels, along with lower estriol and AFP levels, are characteristic findings in the quadruple screening for Down syndrome.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Elevated ß-hCG, PAPP-A, and lower estriol, AFP: This option is incorrect. While elevated ß-hCG and lower estriol are observed in Down syndrome, the presence of PAPP-A and AFP in the answer choice makes it incorrect. PAPP-A is not typically included in the quadruple screening, and AFP levels are lower, not elevated, in Down syndrome.

Option C. Lower ß-hCG, PAPP-A, and elevated estriol, AFP: This option is incorrect. While lower ß-hCG and elevated estriol levels are seen in Down syndrome, the presence of PAPP-A and AFP in the answer choice makes it incorrect.

Option D. Lower ß-hCG, Inhibin, and elevated estriol, AFP: This option is incorrect. While lower ß-hCG and elevated estriol levels are seen in Down syndrome, the presence of inhibin and AFP in the answer choice makes it incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following hormones will be secreted in high amounts by the ovarian granulosa cells during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Estrogen:

  • The ovarian granulosa cells, which surround the developing follicle, produce and secrete high amounts of estrogen during the follicular phase.
  • Estrogen helps to thicken the endometrium, promote the growth of the dominant follicle, and inhibit the release of FSH and LH via negative feedback mechanisms.
  • This hormonal activity is crucial for preparing the endometrium for potential implantation and for the maturation of the follicle leading up to ovulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - FSH (Follicle-stimulating hormone): FSH is indeed important during the follicular phase as it stimulates the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles. However, it is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland, not the ovarian granulosa cells.

Option C - LH (Luteinizing hormone): LH is also secreted by the anterior pituitary gland. LH levels surge just before ovulation, triggering the release of the mature egg from the dominant follicle. This surge marks the transition from the follicular phase to the ovulatory phase

Option D - Progesterone: During the follicular phase, progesterone levels are relatively low. Progesterone production is primarily associated with the luteal phase, which occurs after ovulation. During the luteal phase, the corpus luteum forms and secretes progesterone to maintain the endometrium for a potential pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a heat-sensitive indicator of vaccine viability?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vaccine vial monitor:

  • Heat-sensitive indicator affixed to vaccine vials or packages
  • Provides visual indication of excessive heat exposure
  • Helps determine vaccine viability and safety

Incorrect Options:

Option A - e-VIN: Real-time monitoring system for vaccine stocks and temperatures, not heat-sensitive indicator

Option B - Freeze indicator: Indicates exposure to freezing temperatures, not vaccine viability or heat exposure

Option D - Fridge indicator: Monitors refrigerator temperature for vaccine storage, not specifically a heat-sensitive indicator

questions.text: A young female has history of an incomplete abortion. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mlU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D

  • Uterine synechiae: Uterine synechiae, also known as Asherman's syndrome, refers to the presence of adhesions or scar tissue inside the uterine cavity. These adhesions can result from previous uterine surgery, such as a dilation and curettage (D&C) procedure following a miscarriage. Uterine synechiae can cause amenorrhea by obstructing the menstrual flow. In this case, the history of a incomplete abortion followed by amenorrhea suggests the possibility of uterine synechiae as the cause.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Pituitary dysfunction: Pituitary dysfunction can lead to hormonal imbalances and disrupt the normal menstrual cycle. However, with an FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) level of 6 mlU/ml, which is within the normal range, it is less likely to be the cause in this case.

Option B. Ovarian dysfunction: Ovarian dysfunction, such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or premature ovarian insufficiency (POI), can cause amenorrhea. However, the FSH level of 6 mlU/ml suggests that the ovaries are functioning normally, making ovarian dysfunction less likely in this case.

Option C. First pregnancy: Having a first pregnancy, particularly if it ends in a spontaneous abortion, would not directly cause prolonged amenorrhea. After a spontaneous abortion, the menstrual cycle typically resumes within a few weeks to a few months. Therefore, first pregnancy is an incorrect choice in this context

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible method of contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A

  • Laparoscopic tubal ligation: Laparoscopic tubal ligation, commonly known as "getting your tubes tied," is a surgical procedure that permanently blocks or seals the fallopian tubes. It is considered an irreversible method of contraception because it creates a physical barrier that prevents sperm from reaching the egg, thus eliminating the possibility of fertilization and pregnancy. Once the fallopian tubes are ligated or blocked, it is generally not reversible, although some rare cases of successful tubal ligation reversal have been reported.

Incorrect Option:

Option B. Copper-T: Copper-T, also known as intrauterine device (IUD), is a long-acting reversible contraceptive method. It is a small T-shaped device that is inserted into the uterus to prevent pregnancy. Copper-T works by releasing copper ions, which create an environment that is toxic to sperm, thus preventing fertilization. While Copper-T provides long-term contraception, it is a reversible method. It can be removed at any time if the individual wishes to become pregnant.

Option C. Implanon: Implanon, also known as a contraceptive implant, is a small rod-shaped device that is inserted under the skin of the upper arm. It releases a synthetic hormone called etonogestrel, which prevents ovulation and thickens cervical mucus, making it difficult for sperm to reach the egg. Implanon provides long-term contraception but is also reversible. It can be removed, and fertility can return to normal.

Option D. LNG-IUD: LNG-IUD, or levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device, is another type of intrauterine device that releases a progestin hormone called levonorgestrel. It works by thickening cervical mucus, thinning the uterine lining, and inhibiting sperm movement. Like Copper-T and Implanon, LNG-IUD is a reversible method of contraception. It can be removed, and fertility can be restored.

questions.text: What would be the appropriate course of action for the management of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III in a 40-year-old female?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Colposcopy with LEEP:

  • Colposcopy helps identify the precise location and extent of the cervical abnormality.
  • LEEP (Loop electrosurgical excision procedure) involves removing the abnormal cervical tissue using a wire loop heated by an electrical current.
  • Colposcopy with LEEP is a commonly used and effective management option for CIN III, as it allows for both diagnosis and treatment of the precancerous lesion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hysterectomy: It may be considered in certain cases, especially when the patient does not desire fertility preservation or when there are other factors warranting hysterectomy.

Option B - Trachelectomy: It is typically performed in women with early-stage cervical cancer who desire fertility preservation. It is not the primary management option for CIN III.

Option C - Conization: Conization is a suitable option for CIN III management when fertility preservation is not a concern or in cases where the lesion is large or extends into the endocervical canal

questions.text: A 26 year old female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management?

choices.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.solution:
In the management of a pregnant woman at 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 5 and no end-diastolic blood flow, the correct option is:

Option B. Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks

This situation indicates fetal compromise due to reduced amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios) and absent end-diastolic blood flow, suggesting placental insufficiency. In such cases, delivery may be indicated to prevent further compromise to the fetus. Giving surfactant can help in the lung maturation of the fetus, which is crucial if preterm delivery is anticipated.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Immediate termination might be considered if the fetal condition worsens or if there are signs of acute distress, but the decision should be made considering the overall condition of the mother and the fetus.

Option C. Doing Doppler every day to check for reversion  is not the most appropriate approach. Continuous monitoring and assessment are necessary, but daily Doppler may not be needed unless there are significant changes in the fetal status.

Option D. Terminating after 37 weeks might not be appropriate in this case due to the current compromised fetal condition, which necessitates closer monitoring and potential intervention before term.

questions.text: At what point should a recently positive UTP tested women suffering with cardiac disease taking warfarin therapy be recommended to transition to heparin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C.

  • 12 weeks:

    Anticoagulants are indicated in cases with: (a) Congenital heart disease, (b) pulmonary hypertension, (c) mechanical heart valve, (d) atrial fibrillation. The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and to replace it by heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to 12th week. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) can also be used. This is then replaced by warfarin tablet 3 mg. daily to be taken at the same time each day and continued up to 36 weeks. Thereafter it is replaced by heparin up to 7 days postpartum.  Warfarin is then to be continued

Incorrect Option:

Option A. At the onset of labor: Switching from warfarin to heparin at the onset of labor may not provide adequate anticoagulation coverage throughout the entire duration of labor and postpartum period. It is important to transition to heparin prior to labor to ensure continuous anticoagulation.

Option B. 34 weeks: While 34 weeks is closer to the end of pregnancy, it is still slightly earlier than the recommended time for switching to heparin. The preferred timing is usually closer to term.

Option D. 40 weeks: Waiting until 40 weeks to switch to heparin may result in a shorter duration of anticoagulation coverage before labor begins. It is generally preferred to initiate the switch to heparin earlier to ensure optimal safety for the fetus.

questions.text: What is the potential diagnosis of the patient with a swelling around his knee, whose X-ray image is given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Giant Cell Tumor:

  • Giant cell tumor (GCT) is a locally aggressive, benign bone tumor that primarily affects young adults. It commonly occurs in the long bones, such as the distal femur or proximal tibia. GCT appears as a locally destructive lesion with a characteristic "soap bubble" or "honeycomb" appearance on imaging. 
  • Treatment for giant cell tumors may involve surgical curettage, followed by adjuvant treatments such as bone grafting, and local adjuvants.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Solitary Bone Cyst:

  • A solitary bone cyst, also known as a unicameral bone cyst, is a benign bone lesion that commonly occurs in children and young adults. It typically affects the long bones, such as the femur or humerus. Solitary bone cysts appear as fluid-filled cavities within the bone, causing expansion and thinning of the cortical bone. However, they do not usually result in the specific finger deformity described in the question. Solitary bone cysts are typically asymptomatic and incidentally discovered in imaging studies. They are usually managed conservatively, with monitoring of the lesion's size and possible intervention if symptoms or complications arise.

Option B - Aneurysmal Bone Cyst:

  • An aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is a benign, locally aggressive bone lesion that most commonly occurs in children and young adults. It can affect any bone in the body, including the long bones and the spine. ABCs appear as expansile, cystic lesions filled with blood, which can cause cortical thinning and bone destruction. However, finger involvement is relatively uncommon for aneurysmal bone cysts. They are more commonly found in the long bones or vertebrae. Treatment for aneurysmal bone cysts may involve surgical intervention, such as curettage or embolization, depending on the size, location, and symptoms associated with the lesion.

Option D - Osteoblastoma:

  • Osteoblastoma is a rare, benign bone tumor that usually affects young individuals. It commonly occurs in the spine and long bones but can occur in any bone. Osteoblastomas appear as well-defined, eccentric lesions with a central nidus surrounded by reactive bone. Finger involvement is relatively rare for osteoblastoma. They are more commonly found in weight-bearing bones. The mainstay of treatment for osteoblastoma's is surgical excision, and the prognosis is generally good.

questions.text: Identify the following marked structures.
questions.solution:
Correct marking is Option C

  • Sequestrum:
    • In the context of orthopedics, a sequestrum refers to a fragment of dead or necrotic bone that has become separated from the surrounding healthy bone. It typically occurs as a result of chronic osteomyelitis, which is a bone infection. The sequestrum is a non-viable piece of bone that lacks a blood supply and is often surrounded by a layer of inflammatory tissue called the involucrum. Treatment for a sequestrum usually involves surgical removal to promote healing and prevent the spread of infection.
  • Involucrum:
    • Involucrum is a term used to describe a layer of new bone that forms around a sequestrum or a chronic bone infection. It is part of the body's defense mechanism to isolate and contain the infection. The involucrum serves as a protective barrier, surrounding the sequestrum and helping to limit the spread of infection to healthy bone. It is composed of new bone formation and is often seen in cases of chronic osteomyelitis. Surgical intervention may be required to address the underlying infection and promote healing.
  • Cloaca
    • In anatomy, a cloaca is a structure found in certain animals where the urinary, reproductive, and gastrointestinal tracts open into a common chamber or cavity

questions.text: A polytrauma patient with femur fracture and massive hemorrhage presents to the emergency department, after a road traffic accident. Which of the following is not an immediate treatment consideration in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Internal fixation of femur fracture:  

  • Internal fixation of a femur fracture is an important treatment step for the patient's long-term management and functional recovery.
  • However, in the immediate setting of a polytrauma patient with a femur fracture and massive hemorrhage, it is not the primary consideration. The priority is to address the life-threatening hemorrhage and stabilize the patient's condition before proceeding to definitive fracture management.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Administration of IV crystalloids:

  • IV crystalloids, such as normal saline or lactated Ringer's solution, are commonly used in the resuscitation of trauma patients to replace lost fluids and maintain intravascular volume. This is an important initial step to address hypovolemia and maintain hemodynamic stability.

Option B - Tranexamic acid:

  • Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic medication that helps prevent excessive bleeding and promote clot formation. It is frequently used in trauma patients, especially those with significant hemorrhage, to reduce the risk of bleeding complications. Administering tranexamic acid early can help control bleeding and improve outcomes.

Option C - Check coagulation with thromboelastography:

  • Thromboelastography (TEG) is a diagnostic test that assesses the clotting ability of a patient's blood. It provides information about the patient's coagulation profile and can guide specific interventions to manage any coagulopathy present. Checking coagulation with TEG is an important step in identifying and addressing any coagulation abnormalities that may contribute to ongoing bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity?

choices.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells: 

  • The Nile blue test is used to assess the presence of mature surfactant in the lungs.
  • The presence of more than 50% blue cells suggests the presence of immature surfactant and indicates the need for further lung development.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Lecithin-sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio > 2.5:

  • The L/S ratio measures the ratio of two phospholipids, lecithin, and sphingomyelin, in the amniotic fluid.
  • A ratio greater than 2.5 indicates that the fetus has mature lungs and is capable of producing sufficient surfactant.

Option B: Positive shake test:

  • The shake test, also known as the foam stability test or bubble stability test, is another method used to assess fetal lung maturity.
  • In this test, amniotic fluid is shaken vigorously, and the presence of stable foam indicates the presence of surfactant, suggesting lung maturity.

Option C: Increased phosphatidyl glycerol:

  • Phosphatidyl glycerol (PG) is a phospholipid component of surfactant.
  • Increased levels of PG in the amniotic fluid are associated with fetal lung maturity.
  • The presence of PG is considered a positive indicator of lung maturity.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation.
questions.solution:
Correct option C: Mouth-nose-oesophagus:

  • The correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation is mouth-nose-oesophagus.
  • When suctioning the nose, vagal stimulation may induce the baby to take a deep breath, potentially resulting in aspiration if oral secretions are present.
  • After suctioning the mouth and nose, the next step is to suction the esophagus, or the back of the throat.
  • This step is important because some secretions can accumulate in the esophagus and be aspirated into the airway during resuscitation efforts.
  • By suctioning the esophagus, you can prevent the aspiration of any remaining fluids or material into the airway.

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for an adolescent girl who experiences instances of dropping objects from her hands, particularly in the morning and during exams, without any history of loss of consciousness with EEG showing signs of epileptic spikes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy:

  • JME is a common form of epilepsy that typically begins in adolescence.
  • It is characterized by brief, involuntary muscle jerks or myoclonic seizures, which can result in the dropping of objects.
  • These seizures often occur in the morning upon waking and can be triggered by fatigue, stress, or sleep deprivation.
  • The presence of epileptic spikes on the EEG further supports the diagnosis of JME.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Atypical absence seizures:

  • Atypical absence seizures typically present with a brief loss of awareness, accompanied by subtle motor manifestations such as eye blinking or slight movements.

Option C - Choreo-athetoid epilepsy:

  • Choreo-athetoid epilepsy is a rare form of epilepsy and typically presents with a combination of seizures and abnormal movement patterns.
  • Choreo-athetoid movements refer to involuntary, irregular, and writhing movements.

Option D - Centrotemporal spikes: Centrotemporal spikes, also known as benign rolandic epilepsy, are characterized by seizures that primarily occur during sleep and involve the face, mouth, and throat muscles.

questions.text: A newborn female presents with continuous dribbling of urine. The image below shows the pathology from which the patient is suffering. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bladder exstrophy

  • Bladder exstrophy is a congenital malformation of the urinary system characterized by the incomplete closure of the abdominal wall and anterior wall of the bladder during fetal development.
  • This results in the exposure of the bladder mucosa on the outside of the body.
  • Continuous dribbling of urine is a typical symptom of bladder exstrophy due to the inability to properly contain and control urine.

Incorrect Options: 

Options A, C, and D do not present with continuous dribbling of urine.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis for a 2-year-old child who had a parietal bone fracture from a fall one year ago and is now experiencing a painful parietal swelling that is increasing in size?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B.

  • A growing fracture refers to a fracture in the skull that occurs in early childhood and exhibits progressive enlargement or expansion over time. It is a specific type of skull fracture that can be observed in young children, typically under the age of 3, due to the unique characteristics of their developing skull.
  • In the scenario provided, a 2-year-old child with a history of a fall and parietal bone fracture one year ago now presents with painful and growing parietal swelling. This clinical presentation is consistent with a growing fracture.

Incorrect Option 

Option A. Growing scalp hematoma:

  • A growing scalp hematoma refers to an expanding collection of blood beneath the scalp, typically resulting from trauma. It is characterized by the progressive enlargement of the hematoma. However, in this scenario, the history of a previous parietal bone fracture suggests a more specific diagnosis of a growing fracture rather than a hematoma.

Option C. Subdural hygroma:

  • A subdural hygroma is the accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the subdural space of the brain. It typically occurs as a result of trauma or other pathological conditions. While trauma can be associated with both growing fractures and subdural hygromas, the clinical presentation of a painful and growing parietal swelling in this case is more consistent with a growing fracture.

Option D. Chronic abscess:

  • A chronic abscess refers to a long-standing collection of pus caused by infection. It is less likely in this scenario, as the presentation of a painful and growing parietal swelling is not indicative of an abscess.

questions.text: You have been called to declare the brain death of a 12-year-old child in the ICU. Which of the following is not seen in brain death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D. 

  • Decorticate and decerebrate posturing are abnormal motor responses observed in patients with severe brain injury, but they are not typically seen in brain death. In brain death, there is a complete loss of cerebral and brainstem function, including motor responses. Therefore, the absence of decorticate and decerebrate posturing is consistent with brain death.

Incorrect Option 

Option A. Normal blood pressure without pharmacological support:

  • In brain death, the autonomic centers in the brain that regulate blood pressure and heart rate are typically affected. As a result, maintaining normal blood pressure without the need for pharmacological support is not observed in brain-dead patients. Hypotension or instability of blood pressure requiring vasopressor support is more commonly seen.

Option B. Positive spinal reflexes on stimulation:

  • Brain death is characterized by the irreversible loss of all cerebral and brainstem functions. While the brainstem reflexes may still be present and may include spinal reflexes, they do not override the absence of higher brain functions. Therefore, positive spinal reflexes on stimulation are observed in brain death and are not a differentiating feature.

Option C. Sweating and tachycardia:

  • Sweating and tachycardia are autonomic responses regulated by the brainstem. In brain death, the disruption of the autonomic centers in the brainstem leads to the loss of these responses. Therefore, sweating and tachycardia are not seen in brain-dead patients and can help support the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the clip. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B. 

  • Focal clonic seizures are a type of seizure characterized by rhythmic jerking movements in a specific area of the body. These seizures typically involve one part of the body, such as an arm, leg, or face, and can be repetitive and rhythmic in nature. The movements are usually brief and may occur in clusters.

Incorrect Option 

Option A. Focal tonic seizure:

  • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained muscle contractions or stiffening of a specific body part. This does not match the observed movements in the neonate.

Option C. Spasms:

  • Spasms, also known as infantile spasms or West syndrome, are a specific type of seizure characterized by sudden, brief, and symmetric muscle contractions.
