In the context of lower limb DVT, the presence of multiple flow components in the Doppler waveform is less likely, as the obstruction caused by the blood clot would generally result in diminished or altered flow patterns, leading to a monophasic waveform.

questions.text: Empty thecal sac sign on MRI is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: 

  • Arachnoiditis: Arachnoiditis is a condition characterized by inflammation of the arachnoid, which is one of the membranes that surround the spinal cord and nerves. It can result in the adherence of the arachnoid and the formation of scar tissue, leading to the compression and distortion of the nerves within the thecal sac. This can cause symptoms such as chronic pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness. On MRI, the empty thecal sac sign may be observed, indicating reduced cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the thecal sac due to adhesions or fibrosis.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B. Discitis: Discitis refers to inflammation of the intervertebral disc. It is often caused by infection, although non-infectious causes can also be involved. Discitis can lead to disc space narrowing, destruction of the vertebral endplates, and adjacent vertebral body involvement. However, it does not typically result in an empty thecal sac sign on MRI.

Option C. Vertebral osteomyelitis: Vertebral osteomyelitis is an infection of the vertebral body. It can occur due to bacterial, fungal, or other microbial infections. MRI findings in vertebral osteomyelitis include vertebral body edema, marrow signal abnormality, and enhancement. However, it does not typically result in an empty thecal sac sign.

Option D. Tethered cord syndrome: Tethered cord syndrome occurs when the spinal cord is abnormally attached to surrounding tissues, restricting its normal movement. It can lead to various symptoms, including lower back pain, leg weakness or numbness, and bladder or bowel dysfunction. While tethered cord syndrome may be evaluated with MRI, it does not typically result in an empty thecal sac sign.

questions.text: BCG vaccine provides protection against which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - CNS and disseminated TB:

  • BCG vaccine is most effective against CNS (Central Nervous System) TB and disseminated TB.
  • It primarily prevents severe forms of TB in infants and young children.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pulmonary TB.

Option C - Pulmonary and CNS TB.

Option D - Pulmonary and skeletal T.

questions.text: Pick out the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Cervical rib:

  • A cervical rib is an extra rib that develops above the first rib in the neck region. It is a congenital anomaly and occurs in a small percentage of the population. A cervical rib can potentially compress nearby structures, such as nerves or blood vessels, leading to various symptoms including neck pain, shoulder pain, arm pain, and numbness or weakness in the affected arm. The presence of a cervical rib can be evaluated using imaging studies like X-rays or CT scans.

Incorrect Options:  

Option A. Costochondritis:

  • Costochondritis refers to the inflammation of the cartilage that connects the ribs to the sternum (breastbone). It typically causes localized chest pain and tenderness, which may worsen with movement or deep breathing. The pain is often sharp and can be mistaken for a heart-related condition. However, costochondritis does not involve any structural abnormalities of the ribs or vertebral column.

Option B. Spondylolisthesis:

  • Spondylolisthesis is a condition in which one vertebra slips forward over the vertebra below it. It commonly occurs in the lumbar spine (lower back) and can result in lower back pain, radiating leg pain, and neurologic symptoms if nerve compression occurs. It does not specifically involve the ribs or the presence of a cervical rib.

Option D. Rib fracture:

  • A rib fracture refers to a break or cracks in one or more of the ribs. It typically occurs due to trauma or direct impact on the chest. Rib fractures can cause localized chest pain that worsens with deep breathing, coughing, or movement. Diagnosis is usually confirmed through imaging, such as an X-ray or CT scan, which may reveal the fracture line or displacement of the fractured rib.

questions.text: A large number of tests were done in series. Which of the following will be true?

choices.text: Sensitivity will decrease, and specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase, and specificity will decrease

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sensitivity will decrease, and specificity will increase:

  • Sensitivity and specificity measure a test's performance.
  • Sensitivity: Identifies individuals with the condition (true positives).
  • Specificity: Identifies individuals without the condition (true negatives).
  • Conducting multiple tests can reduce false positives, increasing specificity.
  • Sensitivity may decrease while specificity increases with more tests in series.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sensitivity and specificity will Increase:

  • Wrong, as test performance isn't directly tied to the number of tests.

Option C - Sensitivity and specificity will decrease:

  • Incorrect, as multiple tests don't necessarily lower sensitivity and specificity.

Option D - Sensitivity will increase, and specificity will decrease:

  • Inaccurate; sensitivity usually doesn't rise while specificity drops with more tests.

questions.text: The blood bag is to be disposed of in
questions.solution:
Correct Option B. 

  • The yellow bin is generally designated for the disposal of infectious or biomedical waste. This includes materials contaminated with potentially infectious substances, such as blood or other bodily fluids. Since blood bags contain blood, which is considered biomedical waste, disposing of a blood bag in a yellow bin is the correct option.

Incorrect Option 

Option A. Red bin:

  • The red bin is commonly used for disposing of sharps, such as needles and syringes, which pose a risk of injury or transmission of infections. Blood bags, on the other hand, typically do not fall under the category of sharps. Therefore, disposing of a blood bag in a red bin is not the appropriate option.

Option C. Blue bin:

  • The blue bin is typically used for recyclable materials, such as paper, cardboard, plastic, or glass. Blood bags are not recyclable materials, and their disposal in a blue bin is not appropriate.

Option D. Black bin:

  • The black bin is generally used for non-recyclable general waste or trash. Blood bags, being biomedical waste, should not be disposed of in the black bin.

questions.text: All are true about intestinal transplantation except?

choices.text: Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts
It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions
The most dangerous complication is sepsis
The most common indication is the ischemia

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts:

  • Intestinal transplantation involves the transplantation of the small intestine alone in most cases, rather than multi-visceral grafts.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions: Intestinal transplantation is a complex and challenging procedure, and one reason it is not widely used is the high risk of rejection.

Option C - The most dangerous complication is sepsis: Sepsis, a severe infection that spreads throughout the body, is one of the most dangerous complications following intestinal transplantation.

Option D - The most common indication is ischemia: The most common indications for intestinal transplantation include short bowel syndrome, which can result from surgical resection or congenital malformations, and severe functional gastrointestinal disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding superior mesenteric artery syndrome is false?

choices.text: Third part of the duodenum is compressed
Angle between SMA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Angle between SMA and aorta is more than 70 degrees:

  • The angle between the SMA and the aorta is typically less than 20 degrees, not more than 70 degrees as mentioned in option B.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Third part of the duodenum is compressed: The duodenum, specifically the third part, is compressed between the SMA and the aorta, leading to symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

Option C - Surgical management is by duodenojejunostomy: Surgical intervention, specifically duodenojejunostomy, is often required to relieve the compression and establish a bypass between the duodenum and the jejunum.

Option D - Also known as Wilkie's Syndrome: Superior mesenteric artery syndrome is also known as Wilkie's syndrome, named after the doctor who first described it.

questions.text: Regarding the given box-whisker plot, the true statement is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Mean > Median > Mode :

Option A states that the mean is greater than the median, and the median is greater than the mode, implying a positively skewed distribution. In such distributions, the tail extends towards higher values, affecting the mean more than the median. The mode represents the most common value(s), which can be lower than the mean and median in this scenario.

Incorrect Options: B, C & D

questions.text: The type of renal calculi which is resistant to Extracorporeal Shock-Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cystine:

  • Renal calculi, also known as kidney stones, can be composed of different types of minerals. Each type of stone has its own characteristics and may respond differently to treatment methods such as Extracorporeal Shock-Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL).

  • Cystine stones are formed due to a genetic disorder called cystinuria, which affects the reabsorption of cystine in the kidneys. These stones are composed of cystine, an amino acid. Cystine stones are typically resistant to ESWL due to their hard and dense nature.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Struvite: Struvite stones, also called infection stones, are composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate. These stones can grow rapidly and are often associated with urinary tract infections. Struvite stones are generally amenable to ESWL treatment.

Option C - Calcium oxalate dihydrate: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stones. They can occur in different forms, including calcium oxalate dihydrate. These stones can vary in their response to ESWL, with some calcium oxalate stones being successfully fragmented with shock waves. However, the effectiveness of ESWL may depend on the size, location, and composition of the stone.

Option D - Uric Acid: Uric acid stones form due to high levels of uric acid in the urine. They can be dissolved or fragmented using ESWL. Uric acid stones are generally responsive to ESWL treatment.

questions.text: You have gone to a sub center as part of an audit. How many infants should be registered in a year with a health worker working there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C.

  • 150: This option states that 150 infants should be registered in a year with a health worker at the subcenter. This number is a more reasonable estimate and aligns with the expected workload of a subcenter. It allows for adequate monitoring and provision of healthcare services to a considerable number of infants within a year.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. 50: This number seems quite low considering the population and the expected workload of a subcenter.

Option B. 100: Subcenters often serve a larger population and aim to provide comprehensive healthcare to a significant number of infants.

Option D. 200: While this number is higher than the other options, it may be on the higher side for a typical subcenter. The workload of a health worker at the sub center needs to be balanced to ensure quality care and effective management of healthcare services.

questions.text: What would be the appropriate next step in management for a 22-year-old male presenting with a painless, hard testicular swelling, along with the presence of inguinal, intra-abdominal, or mediastinal lymph nodes on CT scan, elevated AFP levels (> 3000) in blood investigations, and USG findings indicating uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - High inguinal orchidectomy: 

  • This is the recommended initial step in the management of testicular tumors suspected to be malignant. It involves the surgical removal of the affected testicle through a high inguinal incision. The excised testicle is sent for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis and determine the exact type of testicular cancer.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Core needle tract biopsy: Core needle tract biopsy is not the preferred option in this scenario. Testicular tumors are usually managed by surgical excision (orchidectomy) rather than biopsy due to the risk of tumor dissemination along the needle tract.

Option C - FNAC: FNAC (Fine-needle aspiration cytology) is not the preferred option for testicular tumors. It is less commonly used for testicular masses as it may not provide sufficient tissue for accurate histopathological examination and diagnosis.

Option D - Whole-body PET/CT: While whole-body PET/CT can be useful in staging and detecting metastasis in testicular cancer, it is not the initial step in management. Orchidectomy is performed first for histopathological diagnosis, and subsequent staging and imaging studies may be performed to assess the extent of the disease.

questions.text: During an emergency laparotomy performed for a patient with intestinal obstruction, which organ would you initially observe to determine whether it is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Caecum: The caecum is the first part of the large intestine, situated in the lower right abdomen. It receives the contents from the ileum and is involved in the absorption of water and electrolytes. Visualizing the caecum during an emergency laparotomy can help determine if the obstruction is in the large bowel.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A. Ileum: The ileum is the final part of the small intestine, located between the jejunum and the large intestine (cecum). It is responsible for the absorption of nutrients. In cases of small bowel obstruction, the ileum can become dilated and distended.

Option C. Jejunum: The jejunum is the middle part of the small intestine, located between the duodenum and the ileum. It plays a crucial role in nutrient absorption. In cases of small bowel obstruction, the jejunum can also become distended.

Option D. Sigmoid colon: The sigmoid colon is the S-shaped portion of the large intestine that connects the descending colon to the rectum. It is the final part of the colon before the rectum. Sigmoid colon obstruction typically presents as a distinct entity and is not commonly confused with small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of thyroid storm following thyroidectomy?

choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Inadequate patient preparation:

  • Inadequate patient preparation, such as insufficient control of thyroid hormone levels before surgery, can contribute to the occurrence of thyroid storm. Patients with poorly controlled hyperthyroidism or Graves' disease are at a higher risk of developing thyroid storm during or after thyroidectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rough handling of thyroid during surgery: While rough handling of the thyroid during surgery can potentially cause complications such as bleeding or damage to surrounding structures, it is not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm refers to a life-threatening condition characterized by an exaggerated hypermetabolic state, and it is typically related to the release of excessive thyroid hormones into the bloodstream.

Option B - Due to parathyroid gland: The parathyroid glands are small glands located near the thyroid gland. Their primary function is to regulate calcium levels in the body. While complications related to the parathyroid glands can occur during thyroid surgery, they are not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm is specifically associated with the overproduction of thyroid hormones, not parathyroid hormone.

Option D - Infections: Infections, such as surgical site infections, can be a complication of thyroid surgery. However, they are not typically associated with the development of thyroid storm. Infections may cause local symptoms and complications but are not the primary cause of the systemic hypermetabolic state seen in thyroid storm.

questions.text: What are the distinguishing features between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax?

choices.text: Not improving after initial fluid resuscitation

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Breath sounds:

  • Assessing breath sounds can help differentiate between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax. In cardiac tamponade, breath sounds are typically normal because the primary issue is compression of the heart. In tension pneumothorax, on the other hand, there may be absent or decreased breath sounds on the affected side due to lung collapse.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Raised JVP (Jugular Venous Pressure): Both cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax can result in an elevated JVP. However, this is not a specific finding that can differentiate between the two conditions.

Option C - Raised heart rate: Both cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax can lead to an increased heart rate. It is a non-specific finding and cannot be used to differentiate between the two conditions.

Option D - Not improving after initial fluid resuscitation: This option is not specific to either cardiac tamponade or tension pneumothorax. It is more indicative of a lack of response to initial fluid resuscitation and can occur in various conditions.

questions.text: What is the hue of the 16F Foley's catheter?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • Foley's catheters are commonly used for urinary catheterization. The color-coding of Foley's catheters may vary between manufacturers and regions. However, I can provide you with a general overview of the color-coding commonly used for Foley's catheters.
  • Orange: In some color-coding systems, an orange color may be used for a specific size or type of Foley's catheter. However, it is important to note that color-coding can vary, so it's essential to refer to the manufacturer's guidelines or specific institutional protocols for accurate information.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B. Blue: Blue-colored Foley's catheters are also used in some color-coding systems. Again, it is crucial to refer to specific guidelines or protocols to determine the intended meaning of the color.

Option C. Yellow: Yellow is another color that may be used in certain systems to designate a particular size or type of Foley catheter. However, as mentioned earlier, color-coding can differ, so it's important to consult the appropriate guidelines.

Option D. Black: Black is not commonly used as a color for Foley catheters in standard color-coding systems. It is not a typical option for identifying the size or type of catheter.

questions.text: The chi-square test is used to test the significance of the association between:

choices.text: Heart rate and body mass index
Weight of a patient before and after a treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Option C-Sex and type of cancer :

"Sex and type of cancer," is the correct choice for applying the Chi-square test. This involves investigating whether there's a significant association between the variables "sex" (male or female) and "type of cancer" (e.g., lung, breast). The test compares observed frequencies in a contingency table to expected frequencies under the assumption of independence between variables, determining if the association is statistically significant.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A (Age and serum cholesterol level): The association between age and serum cholesterol level would typically be analyzed using correlation or regression analysis rather than the Chi-square test.

Option B (Heart rate and body mass index): Similarly, the association between heart rate and body mass index would be more appropriately analyzed using correlation or regression analysis.

Option D (Weight of a patient before and after treatment): The comparison of weight before and after treatment would typically be analyzed using paired t-tests or other appropriate statistical tests, depending on the specific research design and assumptions.

questions.text: A child was brought to you with complaints of fever, malaise, and a rash. You diagnose the child with measles. What is the recommended period of isolation for this disease?

choices.text: From the onset of rash to 3 days after rash
2 weeks before rash to 1 week after rash
From the onset of rash to 5 days after rash
From the catarrhal stage to 4 days after rash

questions.solution:
Correct Option D.

  • From the catarrhal stage to 4 days after the rash:
    • The catarrhal stage is the early stage of measles, characterized by symptoms like fever, malaise, cough, runny nose, and red eyes.
    • Isolation is recommended from the onset of the catarrhal stage until 4 days after the appearance of the rash.
    • The rash typically develops a few days after the onset of the catarrhal symptoms.

Incorrect Option 

Options A, B, and C do not accurately represent the recommended period of isolation for measles:

Option A. From the onset of rash to 3 days after rash:

  • This option does not cover the catarrhal stage, which is an important period for isolation.

Option B. 2 weeks before rash to 1 week after rash:

  • Isolation for a period of 2 weeks before the rash is not necessary, as measles becomes contagious during the catarrhal stage and after the appearance of the rash.
  • Isolation for only 1 week after the rash is not sufficient, as the contagious period extends beyond that.

Option C. From the onset of the rash to 5 days after the rash:

  • Isolation for 5 days after the rash may not be enough to prevent the transmission of measles, as the contagious period typically extends beyond 5 days after the rash.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is D. From the catarrhal stage to 4 days after the rash is the recommended period of isolation for measles.

questions.text: Please select the appropriate sequence of actions for disaster management.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B. Disaster impact - Response - Rehabilitation - Mitigation:

  • Disaster Impact: Begins with the occurrence of a damaging event.
  • Response: Immediate actions include search and rescue, medical care, and evacuation.
  • Rehabilitation: Focuses on restoring services and infrastructure.
  • Mitigation: Long-term efforts to reduce future disaster impact through planning and infrastructure improvements.

Incorrect Options : A, C & D

questions.text: What is the specific instrument utilized for extracting the graft from the healthy region during split thickness skin grafting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Humby knife:

  • The Humby knife, also known as a dermatome knife, is a specialized instrument used for skin grafting. It is specifically designed to harvest thin slices of skin, making it suitable for split-thickness skin grafting procedures. The Humby knife allows controlled removal of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis from the donor site.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dermatome: A dermatome is the correct instrument used for harvesting split-thickness skin grafts. It is a surgical instrument specifically designed for this purpose. The dermatome allows controlled and precise removal of the epidermis and a variable thickness of the dermis from the healthy donor area. The harvested graft is then transferred to the recipient site, where it is secured and allowed to heal.

Option B - Silver's knife: Silver's knife, also known as a razor or scalpel, is a general surgical instrument used for various purposes, including making incisions and excisions. While a scalpel may be used during certain steps of the split-thickness skin grafting procedure, it is not the primary instrument for graft harvesting.

Option C - Catlin amputating knife: Catlin amputating knife is a type of surgical instrument used for amputations or limb removal. It is not typically used for harvesting split-thickness skin grafts, as its design and purpose are different.

questions.text: The given below device is :
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumatic compression stocking:

  • Pneumatic compression stockings, also known as intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) devices or sequential compression devices (SCDs), are commonly used as a prophylactic measure to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in various clinical settings. 

  • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is the formation of a blood clot in the deep veins of the body, usually in the legs. It can be a serious condition that may lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism if the blood clot dislodges and travels to the lungs.

  • Pneumatic compression stockings are designed to improve blood flow in the legs and reduce the risk of blood clot formation. These stockings are made of inflatable chambers or sleeves that are connected to a device that periodically inflates and deflates the chambers.

  • When the pneumatic compression stockings are worn, the chambers sequentially inflate, applying gentle pressure to the legs in a specific pattern. This pressure helps to promote blood flow in the veins by compressing the superficial veins, thereby reducing venous stasis (slow blood flow) and enhancing venous return (blood flow back to the heart).

  • The sequential inflation and deflation of the chambers create a pumping effect, mimicking the natural movement of the muscles during walking or exercising. This action helps prevent blood from pooling or stagnating in the veins, reducing the likelihood of blood clot formation.

  • Pneumatic compression stockings are often used in situations where individuals are at an increased risk of developing DVT, such as during surgery, prolonged bed rest, or when mobility is limited. They are also utilized for individuals with certain medical conditions or predisposing factors for DVT.

  • It's important to note that pneumatic compression stockings are just one aspect of DVT prevention and are often used in conjunction with other preventive measures. These may include early mobilization, regular leg exercises, pharmacological prophylaxis (such as anticoagulant medications), and maintaining adequate hydration.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Elastic Compression Stockings: The image given above is of Pneumatic compression stockings. 

Option C - Vacuum assisted closure devices: They are used for wound closure and stress ulcers

Option D - Cellulites: Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and tenderness, not shown in the image.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever and cough. His chest radiograph shows an air bronchogram sign. The probable diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Correct Option B.

  • In the given scenario, the presence of fever, cough, and an air bronchogram sign on the chest radiograph suggests the presence of consolidation. Consolidation refers to the filling of the alveoli with fluid, inflammatory exudates, or cellular infiltrates, leading to the solidification of lung tissue. It is commonly seen in conditions such as pneumonia, where the alveoli become filled with inflammatory cells, bacteria, and debris. The air bronchogram sign, which refers to the visualization of air-filled bronchi within the consolidated lung tissue, is a characteristic radiographic finding in consolidation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Pleural effusion: Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity, the space between the lung and the chest wall. It typically presents as blunting of the costophrenic angles on chest radiographs and may cause compression of lung tissue. However, it does not present with the air bronchogram sign seen in the given case.

Option C. Hilar lymphadenopathy: Hilar lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes in the hilar region of the lungs, which is commonly seen in conditions such as tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, or metastatic cancer. It may cause visible lymph node enlargement on chest radiographs, but it does not typically present with the air bronchogram sign seen in the given case.

Option D. Bronchiectasis: Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by abnormal, permanent dilation of the bronchi and bronchioles. It is associated with recurrent infections, excessive mucus production, and impaired clearance of secretions. While bronchiectasis can be seen on chest radiographs and may present with cough and recurrent respiratory infections, it does not typically present with the air bronchogram sign seen in the given case.

questions.text: A drug solution containing 500 mg/5 ml of the drug is given to you. You are provided with a 2 ml syringe (having 10 divisions for each ml). How many divisions of the 2 ml syringe need to be administered to deliver 180 mg of the drug to a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D. 

  • To determine how many divisions of the 2 ml syringe need to be administered to deliver 180 mg of the drug, we need to calculate the volume of the drug solution that contains 180 mg of the drug.
  • Given: Drug concentration: 500 mg/5 ml
  • First, we can calculate the drug concentration per milliliter (mg/ml): 500 mg / 5 ml = 100 mg/ml
  • Next, we can calculate the volume of the drug solution needed to deliver 180 mg of the drug: 180 mg / 100 mg/ml = 1.8 ml
  • Since the provided syringe has 10 divisions for each milliliter, we need to determine the number of divisions for 1.8 ml.
  • Number of divisions = 1.8 ml * 10 divisions/ml = 18 divisions
  • Therefore, 18 divisions of the 2 ml syringe need to be administered to deliver 180 mg of the drug to the patient.

questions.text: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, 2018 was awarded to James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo for which of the following discoveries?

choices.text: Discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm
Discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation
The discovery that matures cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation:

  • Discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, 2018 was awarded to James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo for their discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation. Their work led to the development of immune checkpoint inhibitors, which are drugs that can block the interaction between checkpoint proteins and their receptors, unleashing the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Discovery of mechanisms of autophagy: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, 2016 was awarded to Yoshinori Ohsumi for his discoveries of mechanisms of autophagy. 

Option B - Discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, 2017 was awarded to Jeffrey C. Hall, Michael Rosbash, and Michael W. Young for their discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm. 

Option D - Discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, 2012 was awarded to Sir John B. Gurdon and Shinya Yamanaka for their discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent.
